prior_works.title: Bayesian Poisson Tensor Factorization for Inferring Multilateral Relations
prior_works.authors: Andrew R. Schein, John Paisley, David M. Blei, Hanna M. Wallach
prior_works.role: Probabilistic tensor factorization for sparse multiway count data
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established a principled Poisson CP framework for sparse tensors, motivating DEMOTE’s focus on handling sparse tensor observations while learning latent factors that explain multiway interactions.

prior_works.title: Dynamic Poisson Factorization
prior_works.authors: Laurent Charlin, Rajesh Ranganath, James McInerney, David M. Blei
prior_works.role: Dynamic latent factor model for temporally evolving preferences
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how temporal state-space priors yield evolving embeddings from sparse, time-stamped data, which DEMOTE generalizes by learning continuous-time entity trajectories with graph-coupled dynamics.

prior_works.title: Temporal Regularized Matrix Factorization for High-dimensional Time Series Prediction
prior_works.authors: Hsiang-Fu Yu, Nikhil Rao, Inderjit S. Dhillon
prior_works.role: Time-aware factorization with autoregressive temporal smoothness
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Inspired DEMOTE’s core idea of explicitly modeling temporal structure in latent factors, replacing hand-crafted AR regularizers with a learned neural reaction term and diffusion coupling.

prior_works.title: Graph Convolutional Matrix Completion
prior_works.authors: Rianne van den Berg, Thomas N. Kipf, Max Welling
prior_works.role: Graph-based propagation on user–item bipartite graphs for sparse observations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Motivated DEMOTE’s construction of a multi-partite graph from observed tensor entries and the use of graph propagation to denoise and share information across sparsely observed entities.

prior_works.title: Diffusion Improves Graph Learning
prior_works.authors: Johannes Klicpera, Aleksandar Bojchevski, Stephan Günnemann
prior_works.role: Diffusion-based propagation (e.g., personalized PageRank) for capturing long-range dependencies
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the diffusion paradigm that DEMOTE adapts to co-evolve correlated entity embeddings via graph Laplacian-driven smoothing over the multi-partite interaction graph.

prior_works.title: Neural Ordinary Differential Equations
prior_works.authors: Ricky T. Q. Chen, Yulia Rubanova, Jesse Bettencourt, David Duvenaud
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Underpins DEMOTE’s modeling of embedding trajectories as solutions to learned differential equations, enabling continuous-time evolution with data-driven reaction terms.

prior_works.title: Latent Ordinary Differential Equations for Irregularly-Sampled Time Series
prior_works.authors: Yulia Rubanova, Tian Qi Chen, David Duvenaud
prior_works.role: Latent ODEs for sparse, irregular temporal observations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Directly motivates DEMOTE’s ability to learn smooth latent trajectories from sparsely and irregularly observed entries, aligning with its neural reaction process per entity.

synthesis_narrative:
DEMOTE’s core contribution—estimating dynamic embeddings for tensor entities via a neural diffusion–reaction process on a multi-partite graph—sits at the intersection of three lines of work. First, probabilistic tensor and matrix factorization for sparse data (Schein et al., 2015; Charlin et al., 2015; Yu et al., 2016) established that temporal structure and appropriate likelihoods are crucial when observations are sparse and time-stamped. These works introduced temporal priors or autoregressive regularization to encourage smooth factor evolution, but relied on hand-crafted dynamics and did not explicitly couple entities through observed interaction structure.
Second, graph-based recommendation and diffusion methods (van den Berg et al., 2018; Klicpera et al., 2019) showed that constructing graphs from observations and propagating information over these graphs is an effective remedy for sparsity. DEMOTE generalizes the bipartite user–item graph to a multi-partite graph induced by tensor entries and replaces discrete GCN-style layers with continuous diffusion, allowing correlated entities across modes to co-evolve.
Third, continuous-time neural dynamics (Chen et al., 2018; Rubanova et al., 2019) provided the machinery to learn trajectories from irregular, sparse temporal signals. DEMOTE instantiates this by using a neural reaction term per entity to capture idiosyncratic evolution, while a graph diffusion term captures shared trends across related entities. By fusing temporal factorization, graph diffusion, and neural ODEs, DEMOTE yields a principled, data-driven dynamic tensor decomposition that captures both commonalities and personalities in entity evolution under extreme sparsity.
